Cristóvão Colombo, 2265 São José do Rio Preto São Paulo 15054-000 Brazil Graphical abstract Synthesis and characterization of a copper mixed metal oxide obtained from hydrotalcite precursor as well as catalytic runs for ethanol conversion to 1-butanol are described. Applying the surface response model, the reaction was optimized reaching an ethanol conversion of 79.6% into gaseous phase (69% of yield) and condensed phase (31% of yield) products using a batch reactor at 350 °C for 5 h. The main product of the condensed phase was 1-butanol with 25.4% yield and 32% selectivity, these results being among the higher ones reported for this reaction in the literature. Recycling catalyst experiments demonstrated that, for at least four cycles, the ethanol conversion remains almost constant but the 1-butanol yield and selectivity both decreased. XRD, EPR, surface area measurements and acidity/basicity experiments carried out after the first and fourth catalyst recycling cycles show major modifications in the initial mixed metal oxide structure and copper oxidation state indicating that the active catalytic species increases during the first catalytic run. Keywords Metal mixed oxides Copper-modified hydrotalcite Ethanol conversion 1-Butanol 1 Introduction Ethanol, derived from sugar fermentation, is the biofuel produced in largest volume from renewable sources [1]. Although it is mainly used as fuel for combustion engines, ethanol has been studied as a possible raw material in the chemical industry to produce hydrogen [2–5], butadiene [6,7], 1-butanol [8], acetaldehyde [9] and p-xylene [10] representing an alternative source of carbon-containing compounds in place of petroleum. Among these products, 1-butanol is desirable due to its possible use as a fuel, as an industrial raw material (for the production of esters, ethers and resins) and as a solvent [11]. Also, 1-butanol is noncorrosive, is immiscible in water [8] and has an energy density of 36.6 kJ g−1, higher than ethanol (30 kJ g−1) and closer to gasoline (90%), making it a possible alternative to high-octane rating fuels [12], an alternative to biodiesel in diesel mixtures and an excellent substitute for ethanol in gasoline blends [13]. Although this reaction makes a key contribution for greener industrial processes, the ethanol conversion to higher molecular weight products remains a challenge and the process has been studied less than the reforming reaction [14,15]. The above mentioned products can be obtained through two distinct reaction pathways, although both start from ethanol. Hydrogen is obtained by the ethanol reforming reaction, in which ethanol is fully converted into gaseous products [2,16] Other compounds, mostly 1-butanol, are obtained from the Guerbet reaction [17]. This endothermic process is the most accepted route for ethanol-based coupling reactions to increase the number of carbons atoms in the chain consisting of at least four steps: (i) ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde, (ii) the aldol coupling reaction (iii) dehydration of the products formed by the aldol reaction, and finally (iv) two successive hydrogenations yielding 1-butanol [8], as shown in Fig. 1 . Furthermore, 1-butanol may restart the cycle, generating longer carbon chain compounds. Although the Guerbet reaction is a key contributor to the development of greener industrial processes, ethanol conversion to higher molecular weight products remains a challenge and has been studied less than the ethanol reforming reaction. The Guerbet reaction requires the utilization of a catalyst. Three main classes of heterogeneous catalysts have been used for the Guerbet reaction: hydroxyapatite [18] metal oxides [19], and magnesium-aluminum mixed metal oxides (MMO) obtained from hydrotalcite calcination at high temperatures [20]. Hydrotalcites are layered double hydroxides (LDH) composed of different Mg2+/Al3+ molar ratios being employed as catalyst precursors [21]. Mixed metal oxides derived from LDH precursors have attracted attention because different metal ions can be easily incorporated in the LDH precursor [22] (replacing Mg2+ or Al3+ ions) modifying the catalytic properties of these MMOs by changing the acidity and basicity of the solid and the surface area resulting in a possible fine-tuning of the selectivity and product yields of the Guerbet reaction. Substitution of Mg2+ by Cu2+ ions on LDH increases the number of acid sites in the derived MMO, improving the ethanol dehydrogenation activity [23]. Also, copper demonstrated high hydrogenation activity that is a key step in 1-butanol formation [17]. It has already been reported that copper-doped metal oxides derived from hydrotalcites used in the Guerbet reaction showed encouraging results [17,24,25] but there is still a lack of information about how reaction parameters (time, temperature and catalyst load) can influence the ethanol conversion and the product formation. Also, the structural properties of catalysts after recycling are not yet well explored. Here, a copper-modified hydrotalcite (substituting 10 mol % of Mg2+ by Cu2+, Cu10LDH) was synthesized as pre-catalyst and this material was calcined at 450 °C to obtain the respective mixed metal oxide (Cu10MMO) which was then used as the catalyst for the conversion of ethanol to 1-butanol. The modified materials were characterized by a series of spectroscopic techniques: Fourier Transform Infra-Red (FTIR), X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), method of BET (Brunauer, Emmett and Teller), Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The surface response model was applied aiming to maximize the ethanol conversion reaction to 1-butanol in batch autoclave reactors. Also, catalyst-recycling experiments and catalyst characterization after the reaction cycles were conducted. 2 Methods 2.1 Synthesis The copper-modified hydrotalcite (Cu10LDH, catalyst precursor) was prepared by the co-precipitation method [26] using a 3:1 M ratio previously studied (sum of divalent cations Mg2+ and Cu2+ = 3 and trivalent cation Al3+ = 1). A solution of Na2CO3 (0.2 mol L−1) was prepared and the pH adjusted to 10 using a NaOH solution (4 mol L−1). A solution containing Mg(NO3)2.6H2O (2.55 mol L−1), Al(NO3)3.9H2O (0.96 mol L−1) and Cu(NO3)2.3H2O (0.42 mol L−1), which substituted 10% of Mg2+, was slowly dripped into the carbonate solution under controlled temperature (60 °C) and constant stirring. Once all the solution had been added, the resulting slurry was aged for 12 h at 60 °C. The solid was then filtered, washed with deionized water and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The same procedure was followed to obtain a non-modified hydrotalcite (LDH) used as the standard material for the characterization analyses and reaction control. The resulting hydrotalcites were calcined at 450 °C for 5 h giving rise to the MMO (reference material) and Cu10MMO used as catalysts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of LDHs and MMOs were obtained in a MiniFlex300 diffractometer (Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan), using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) operating at 40 kV and 30 mA at 2θ in the range of 4 to 70 degrees. FTIR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 400 cm−1 on a Spectrum Two spectrophotometer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, USA) fitted with an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) device. The EPR measurements were performed using an EMX plus spectrometer (Bruker, Billerica, USA), operating at X-Band microwave frequency (9.77 GHz). The samples were placed in a quartz capillary tube (1 mm internal diameter) and the experiments were carried out at room temperature. All thermal analysis measurements were carried out using a TGA 4000 thermogravimetric balance– (PerkinElmer, Waltham, USA) and the mass loss was measured from 100 °C to 650 °C (10 °C min−1) in N2 flow (20 mL min−1) [20]. For the thermogravimetric temperature-programmed reduction (TG-TPR) experiments, the sample was heated to 650 °C in an ethanol saturated N2 atmosphere (20 mL min−1), and the metal reduction temperature was determined by the mass change resulting from the water lost due to the metal reduction (Eq.1) (1) 2 C H 3 C H 2 O H → Δ 2 C H 3 C H O + H 2 H 2 + M O → M 0 + H 2 O Mixed metal oxide basicity and acidity were determined by the CO2 or n-butylamine adsorption/desorption method in a TGA-4000 thermogravimetric analyzer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, USA). Previously, 20 mg of samples were treated at 450 °C for 10 min under 20 mL min−1 flow of He. After that, 20 mL min−1 of CO2 or 20 mL min−1 of N2 saturated with n-butylamine was added for 10 min for adsorption. Then, the samples were heated from 35 to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 and the loss of mass caused by the removal of the absorbed CO2 or n-butylamine was monitored and used to determine the number and distribution of the basic and acid sites. This design generated 40 experiments with 6 replicates in central points for ethanol conversion (Table S1). The experiments were carried out in duplicate and the mean value was adopted. For each catalytic run, 3 mL of anhydrous ethanol and the needed amount of catalyst were loaded into the reactors. Anhydrous ethanol was used in the later tests because it presents (on average) greater conversion of ethanol to condensable products. The reactions were carried out in a muffle furnace (at 266, 280, 300, 320 and 334 °C) and for a time period of 1, 2, 3.5, 5 and 6 h as the factorial design experiments predict. After a predetermined reaction time, the reactor was cooled in water to quench the reaction. (Warning! High pressure inside the reactor. Care must be taken). The reactors were opened in a special apparatus to measure the amount of gas generated during the reaction (described in details in SI). The gaseous products were conducted into a graduated cylinder filled with water and the volume displaced was correlated with the amount of gas generated [28]. For catalyst recycling tests, the catalyst was washed with hexane, centrifuged and dried at 60 °C until the solvent had evaporated completely. To guarantee the same catalyst load in each cycle, the recycling experiments started with four reactors using the reaction conditions described before. After each run, the catalyst from all reactors was collected, dried and redistributed for the next reaction cycle. Due to the material lost in the course of these procedures, in the fourth reaction cycle, the reaction was conducted with only three instead of four reactors simultaneously. 2.5 Sample preparation, chromatographic analysis and calculations The condensed phase products were separated from the catalyst by centrifugation at 10 krpm for 10 min and filtrated in High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) syringe filters (0.22 μm X 25 mm). Table 2 shows the crystallographic data such as the distance between cations in the lamellar layer (a), the height of the unit cell (c) crystallite size (D) and basal spacing (I003). Copper-modified hydrotalcite (Cu10LDH) parameters are consistent with the ones found in the literature [29,30]. However, the addition of copper causes an increase in basal spacing (I003) and a reduction in peak width at half height (β003) indicating decreased crystallinity [31]. The cell parameter (a) is calculated by 2x d(110). There is no significant difference in this parameter comparing Cu10LDH and the reference material (LDH), suggesting a successful Cu incorporation in the layers. Parameter (c) was calculated by 3/2 [(d(003)+(2d(006))] and it can be seen that the insertion of copper decreases this parameter. Parameter (D) is the particle diameter and uses the mean of planes 003 and 006 [32]. As shown in Table 2, the addition of copper results in an increase in particle size of 23% compared to the material without copper. The crystallographic patterns of LDHs were transformed by calcination as can be seen in Fig.1 (C and D). The XRD patterns of the MMO and Cu10MMO show three peaks: (111), (200) and (220) characteristic of periclase (MgO) (JCPDS 89–7746) and spinel (MgAl2O4) (JCPDS-45946). After calcination, the peaks attributed to other oxides are not seen, indicating the formation of amorphous material. Parameters (a) and (D) were calculated using the plane (Miller index) (200) and can be found in Table 2. The addition of copper decreases the crystallite size (D), I200 and (a) indicating compaction and structural collapse but without the formation of any crystalline regions. The Cu10LDH catalyst thermogravimetric analysis shows two thermal events (Supplementary Information Fig. S1). The first mass loss (14.8%) occurs around 180 °C, and is correlated with the loss of adsorbed and interlayer water, without structure collapse [33]. The second mass loss (23.9%) occurs around 300 °C and is due to lamellar dehydroxylation and decarbonation resulting in collapse of the structure [34]. The TPR analyses were performed using ethanol saturated N2 atmosphere as the reducing agent (Supplementary Information Fig. S1). During the catalyst reduction, H2O is formed and consequently there is a mass loss at temperatures higher than 100 °C. The reduction of the copper containing catalyst shows at least two reduction peaks, the first one at low temperatures is associated with Cu+2 reduction to Cu+1, the second one is observed at higher temperatures and is associated to Cu+1 reduction to Cu0. [29–32]. The reduction starts at 550 °C and finishes at 585 °C, the maximum reduction temperatures associated with a mass loss being 564 °C. Moreover, Karthikeyan and collaborators [14] showed that high calcination temperatures decrease the number of basic sites and keep the number of acid sites in the MMOs derived from hydrotalcites almost constant. Since equilibrium between the number of basic and acid sites is desirable, the calcination was carried out at 450 °C. Surface area, basicity, and acidity data for mixed metal oxides are summarized in Table 3 . The partial substitution of Mg2+ by Cu2+ (Cu10MMO) slightly decreases the surface area (178 to 171 m2 g−1) indicating that the Mg2+ substitution by Cu2+ did not deeply modify the material structure, as already observed in the XRD diffractograms. The TPD technique provides the strength and number of acid and basic sites on the surface of the catalyst determined by the desorption temperature and the peak area, respectively [37]. The MMO and Cu10MMO oxides presented three desorption peaks for acidity and basicity determination as follows: weak sites (between 80 and 180 °C), medium sites (usually between 180 and 380 °C) and strong sites (at temperatures around at 630 °C) [38,39]. The TPD profiles for MMO and Cu10MMO oxides are shown in Supplementary Information Fig. S2 Table 3 shows the acid and basic site distribution of the MMOs. Compared to the reference material (MMO), the Cu10MMO oxide showed an increase in both weak and strong basic sites, consequently increasing the overall oxide basicity. However, regarding acid sites, the copper led to an increase in weak sites and a slight decrease in medium and strong acid sites in comparison with the MMO but the overall acidity was higher than the reference material, following the same tendency as that observed for the basic sites. In the Cu10MMO material, there is a ratio of basic and acid sites (B/A) equal to 1.55. The acid-base bifunctionality is necessary for the Guerbet reaction and has already been confirmed in recent literature [40]. This amphoteric property is important since ethanol dehydrogenation to acetaldehyde occurs at weak/medium basic sites, the aldolization of aldehydes occurs at basic medium or strong sites and finally, dehydration and hydrogenation occur on acid sites [19]. The LDHs infrared spectra (Supplementary Information, Fig. S3) showed a wide and intense band around 3400 cm−1 attributed to vibrational stretching of OH groups (νOH) and water molecules present on lamellae surfaces [41]. There is a discrete absorption at 1650 cm−1 attributed to water molecule vibration present in interlamellar layers and the intense band at 1350 cm−1 indicates the carbonate ion in the interlamellar region [42]. Bands in regions below 1000 cm−1 correspond to particular vibrations between the metal and oxygen bonds [33]. In general, no substantial differences were found in the IR spectra. The SEM-EDS micrographs of MMO and Cu10MMO are depicted in the Supplementary Information, Figs. S4 and S5. The rosette morphology, typical for layered material, is not seen because this pattern is destroyed by calcination, as observed by Coelho et al. [43]. The micrographs of copper-modified materials showed a rounded shape profile, suggesting the formation of agglomerates. Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) provides information about the different elements present in the outermost superficial layer of the material [30]. EDS spectra, shown in Fig. S5, indicate the presence of Cu+2, Mg+2 and Al+3 and the percentages of elements in different positions on the sample are practically unchanged, meaning there is a good distribution of the metallic elements. Altogether, the techniques used show that the copper-modified LDH and MMO were successfully synthesized and the introduction of copper into the hydrotalcite structure mainly modifies the balance of basic and acid sites in the catalyst but not the overall structure of the material. 3.2 Reaction optimization and catalytic assays As a first attempt to optimize the ethanol conversion reaction, catalytic runs were performed at a temperature of 280 °C, using 30 mg of catalyst and 2 h of reaction, resulting in 20% ethanol conversion. In this experiment, only 2% of the condensed phase was 1-butanol. By using this preliminary result as a guide, the experimental planning was carried out aiming to optimize the ethanol conversion and 1-butanol yield by correlating three variables: catalyst load (X1), reaction time (X2) and temperature (X3). The Supplementary Information depicts the full table of response parameters (Table S1) and analysis of variance (ANOVA) results for the model (Table S2). Analyzing the response surface graphics, Figs. 3 A and B, generated by the model, for the three-independent initial variables for ethanol conversion, the reaction time variable (X2) is the most significant one, followed by temperature (X3) and catalyst load (X1). Also, the interactions between the variables were not significant as observed by the Pareto diagram (Supplementary Information, Fig. S6). The response surface graphic, (Fig. 3A) confirms the model prediction, since the ethanol conversion is more sensitive to reaction time than to catalyst load. In addition, correlating the reaction time (X2) and reaction temperature (X3) variables and the latter is still the most important one for the ethanol conversion yield as shown in the response surface plot (Fig. 3B). As can be seen, at temperatures below 300 °C ethanol conversion was lower than 25%. However, at temperatures above 300 °C, conversion easily exceeds 30%, even for a shorter reaction time (3 h). The highest ethanol conversion achieved was approximately 60% at 340 °C for a reaction time of 5 h and 100 mg of catalyst. The surface response model can be described as functions of real coded variables (X1, X2, and X3) as shown in Eq. 2. Fixing the maximum temperature at 350 °C the model shows that using a catalyst load of 150 mg and 5 h of reaction, the expected ethanol conversion would be 81%. Applying the reaction parameters furnished by the model, the reaction was carried out reaching an ethanol conversion of 79.6%, this value being close to the model prediction. Since these conditions proved to be the best ones, they were used as standard for studies dealing with 1-butanol selectivity and catalyst recycling. Regarding the composition of the products, they can be divided into two phases-gaseous and condensed. The gaseous products correspond to 69% of the total. These gas phase products were not identified and quantified individually but the total amount of gases generated was estimated by the displacement volume. As reported in the literature [6–9] for similar reactions, they can be assumed to be a mixture with H2 [44], CO, CO2, CH4 and ethylene as their major constituents. The condensed phase contributes with the other 31% of the reaction products. The most representative products in the condensed phase are 1-butanol and ethyl acetate, both expected as Guerbet condensation products. Fig. 4 summarizes the ethanol conversion, the portions corresponding to the gaseous and condensed phases and the main products of the latter (1-butanol and ethyl acetate) with corresponding yields and selectivities. 1-butanol was more abundant than ethyl acetate. The minor products (sixty identified compounds) that contribute to 67% of the condensed phase are composed of esters (mostly ethyl and butyl butanoates), higher carbon chain alcohols (1-hexanol, 4-nonanol) and ketones (3-hexanone, 2-heptanone). Table S3 in the Supplementary Material summarizes the minor products identified by GC–MS. The proposed reaction pathway for 1-butanol and ethyl acetate formation is depicted in Fig. 5 [45]. As can be seen, there are two key intermediates for the formation of the products, assuming the Guerbet reaction: acetaldehyde and butyraldehyde. In the condensed phase analysis, after 5 h of reaction, these two intermediates were not identified, suggesting that once formed on the catalyst surface, these species are readily converted into ethyl acetate and/or 1-butanol. The major selectivity presented for 1-butanol in the reaction may be explained by two factors. Under the reaction conditions, reduction reactions are more feasible since, during ethanol dehydrogenation, metal-hydride species are probably being formed on the catalyst surface. This hypothesis is strongly supported by the possible high partial pressure of hydrogen inside the batch reactor. From this perspective, butyraldehyde reduction to 1-butanol is benefited instead of 1-ethoxyethanol oxidation. The presence of Cu+2 in the catalyst plays an important role in the 1-butanol selectivity. The literature indicates that Cu+2 incorporated in a heterogeneous catalyst enhances the hydrogenation activity, since the hydride formations and its transfer over copper is favored. Also, the copper incorporated in the hydrotalcite structure increased the number of basic sites and acid sites. Thus, the increase in the acidity of the catalyst should enhance the metal-hydride formation, enabling the butyraldehyde hydrogenation to 1-butanol. Recently, Barta and collaborators [17] converted ethanol to 1-butanol using copper and nickel (both metal ions in 10 mol % substitution of Mg2+) modified mixed metal oxides derived from hydrotalcites, reaching a 1-butanol yield of 21.7% and 72% of selectivity. However, this catalyst showed an ethanol conversion of 47.6% at 310 °C. Regarding our study, Barta’s catalysts has similarities to the catalyst used in this work, the obtained results follow the same tendency observed, because the higher ethanol conversion and 1-butanol yield in the present work (79.6 and 25.4%, respectively) is probably due to the higher temperatures employed. However, the higher temperature is also probably responsible for the lower selectivity (32%). 3.3 Catalyst recycling Catalyst recycling is an important issue in the ethanol conversion when considering upscaling for industrial application. Also, taking into account the environmental point of view, multiple catalyst recycling diminishes the necessity of catalyst synthesis and, consequently, increased raw material requirements. Recycling experiments were conducted using the Cu10MMO catalyst in four sequential cycles. Fig. 6 shows the ethanol conversion, 1-butanol and ethyl acetate formation and product selectivity for the recycling experiments. As depicted in Fig. 6, after three recyclings the ethanol conversion remains almost constant (ranging from 79 to 73%), demonstrating that the catalyst is still active. However, product distribution changed, indicating that 1-butanol production decreased (from 25.4 to 14%) while the ethyl acetate production increased. Thus, the selectivity changed, diminishing for 1-butanol (from 32 to 20%) and slight increasing for ethyl acetate (from 10 to 12%). Trying to address the catalyst surface behavior during the catalytic runs, XRD experiments were performed. Fig. 7 shows the diffractograms for the Cu10MMO; (A) after the reaction, (B) after the first catalytic cycle and (C) after the fourth cycle. The diffractogram (B) shows that the Cu10MMO underwent major modifications, indicating the formation of three different oxidation states ranging from +2 to 0, as indicated in the Fig.7. Furthermore, the peak shape changed significantly in diffractograms (B) and (C) indicating that, after the reaction, the size of the crystallites increased. This new material proved to be stable since it was still active after at least four reaction cycles. To confirm the changes in the copper oxidation during the catalytic reactions, EPR experiments were performed. Fig. 8 shows the spectra of the MMO (A) before and (B) after the first catalytic cycle. The spectrum of Fig.8(A) indicates that MMO is composed of Cu2+ ions in an octahedral coordination arrangement, showing three distinct g values (g1 = 2.55, g2 = 2.15 and g3 = 2.05). After the first catalytic run, as shown in Fig. 8(B), the Cu2+ signal almost disappeared, with only a low-intensity signal with a g value of 2.05. This observation indicates that the Cu2+ ions in the Cu10MMO structure were reduced to Cu+ and/or Cu0 species, due to the hydrogen production during the ethanol reactions. However, there is still a small amount of Cu2+ in the Cu10MMO structure, shown by the presence of the low-intensity signal seen. The change in the copper oxidation state seen in the EPR experiments corroborates the XRD observations. The surface area and XRD data are coherent since the increase in the crystallites in the material leads to a decrease in the surface area (from 178 ± 1–98 ± 2). Figs. 7 and 8 show the real nature of the catalytic species. It is clear that the fresh Cu10MMO underwent copper oxidation and structure modifications, giving rise to a new oxide material during the first catalytic run and this material was still catalytically active over at least four cycles. The copper oxidation state and catalyst structural changes are consequences of the reductive environment inside the reactor, due to the hydrogen generated during the Guerbet reaction. Since it is well established that Cu2+ is easily reduced under a hydrogen atmosphere and at higher temperatures [45] the modifications seen in the catalyst are expected. Also, the high pressure inside the reactor may contribute to the material phase change observed. Similar results regarding XRD and catalyst surface area modification during the Guerbet reaction were recently reported by Ford and co-workers [46]. Their results were obtained with 20% Cu2+ substitution in the catalyst instead of the 10% used in this work and under different reaction conditions using Cl− as additive for the reactions. However, since the results reported in the literature and herein follow the same tendency, it is indicative that the mixed metal oxide used as a catalyst for the Guerbet reaction behaves similarly, even under slightly different reaction conditions. 4 Conclusion Ethanol conversion to 1-butanol was achieved with a 25.4% yield and 32% selectivity in the condensed phase employing a copper mixed metal oxide as the catalyst after 5 h of reaction at 350 °C, achieving ethanol conversion of 79.6%. The surface response model was applied to obtain the best reaction conditions based on the reaction time, temperature and catalyst load. This showed that reaction time is the most important variable for the reaction. The catalyst maintained the ethanol conversion and main condensed phase products over four recycling cycles, clearly indicating the robustness of the synthesized material. Although the ethanol conversion over a number of recycling cycles was almost constant, the 1-butanol yield and selectivity changed, probably due to structural modifications on the catalyst surface. Due to the reductive nature of the products generated by the Guerbet reaction, the MMO suffered structural modifications and copper oxidation state changes, as shown by XRD and EPR, indicating that the catalyst is a mixture of Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0 species generated in situduring the first reaction cycle. coredata.dc:description: Synthesis and characterization of a copper mixed metal oxide obtained from hydrotalcite precursor as well as catalytic runs for ethanol conversion to 1-butanol are described. Applying the surface response model, the reaction was optimized reaching an ethanol conversion of 79.6% into gaseous phase (69% of yield) and condensed phase (31% of yield) products using a batch reactor at 350 °C for 5 h. The main product of the condensed phase was 1-butanol with 25.4% yield and 32% selectivity, these results being among the higher ones reported for this reaction in the literature. Recycling catalyst experiments demonstrated that, for at least four cycles, the ethanol conversion remains almost constant but the 1-butanol yield and selectivity both decreased. XRD, EPR, surface area measurements and acidity/basicity experiments carried out after the first and fourth catalyst recycling cycles show major modifications in the initial mixed metal oxide structure and copper oxidation state indicating that the active catalytic species increases during the first catalytic run.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective 1-butanol obtained from ethanol catalyzed by mixed metal oxides: Reaction optimization and catalyst structure behavior
